org.integratedmodelling.thinklab.api.runtime
Interface ISession

All Superinterfaces:
IOntology, IResource
public interface ISession
extends IOntology

A Session is a temporary concept space that contains all instances that are created during a user session. The ontology metadata also contain details about session creation. Typically, all operations on sessions are synchronized.

Author:
Ferdinando Villa

Each session has a unique ID assigned by the Knowledge manager.

Returns:
the session's ID.

getSessionProperties

java.util.Properties getSessionProperties()
A session must have properties that users and plugins can set. This method must return a valid properties object.

Returns:
the session's properties.

addListener

void addListener(IThinklabSessionListener listener)
                 throws ThinklabException
The knowledge manager may pass one or more session listeners to a newly created session using this function. The function has the option of throwing an exception if it does not want to deal with listeners, but should not accept them and then ignore them. If listeners are accepted, the session commits to calling the objectCreated() and objectDeleted() on FIRST-CLASS OBJECTS ONLY (those that are not secondary to other objects when loaded from sources or created by the API) appropriately. The sessionCreated and sessionDeleted methods are called by the knowledge manager, so the session doesn't need to worry about them.

Parameters:
listener -
Throws:
ThinklabException

write

void write(java.lang.String file)
           throws ThinklabException

Write all current contents of ontology on passed ontology file.

NOTE: this will remove all non-validated instances, rendering all relative objects meaningless and their use dangerous. This may change.

Parameters:
file -
Throws:
ThinklabException

createConcept

IConcept createConcept(Polylist list)
                       throws ThinklabException
Sessions must be capable of creating temporary concepts from a list specification. These concepts can only restrict "global" ones by specifying owl:hasValue restrictions. The list syntax is very similar to the one used for instances.

Specified by:
createConcept in interface IOntology
Parameters:
list -
Returns:
Throws:
ThinklabException

createObject

IInstance createObject(java.lang.String name,
                       IConcept parent)
                       throws ThinklabException
Create object of passed type. Object is all yours to define.

Parameters:
name - A name for the new object. Must be unique or exception is thrown.
parent - the instance parent concept.
Returns:
a new unvalidated IInstance.
Throws:
ThinklabException - if anything wrong. FIXME must return a garbage collected instance, if we ever manage to implement it.

createObject

IInstance createObject(java.lang.String concept)
                       throws ThinklabException
Create object of passed type. Object is all yours to define. The object must be validated using validate() before it can be used. Name of object is automatically assigned.

Parameters:
concept - a string representing the semantic type of the parent concept.
Returns:
a new unvalidated IInstance
Throws:
ThinklabException - if anything wrong. * FIXME must return a garbage collected instance, if we ever manage to implement it.

createObject

IInstance createObject(java.lang.String name,
                       Polylist definition)
                       throws ThinklabException
Create object from list definition. Can be used to copy instances from a session to another or from the KB. Careful with nested instances though. Instance shoud be completely defined by list, so it is validated before it's returned.

Parameters:
name - Unique name for the new object. Use getUniqueObjectName() if no clue. The name is not a property of the object, so it can't be passed in the list (this may change).
definition - the list defining a new instance.
Returns:
a new validated Instance.
Throws:
ThinklabException - if anything wrong. FIXME must return a garbage collected instance, if we ever manage to implement it.

createObject

IInstance createObject(Polylist polylist)
                       throws ThinklabException
Create instance, using made up name. Identical to createObject(String, Polylist) otherwise.

Parameters:

properties - TODO

Returns:

loadObjects

java.util.Collection<IInstance> loadObjects(java.net.URL url)
                                            throws ThinklabException
Read in objects from the given URL. What can be read depends on the implementation, but it should support OWL and OPAL at least.

Parameters:
url - a URL to read from
Returns:
a collection of the main-level IInstances (those that are defined in the main level, i.e. are not "linked" to others).
Throws:
ThinklabException - if anything goes wrong FIXME must return garbage collected instances, if we ever manage to implement it.

retrieveObject

IInstance retrieveObject(java.lang.String name)
Retrieve the named object or null if no such object exists in session.

Parameters:
name - an object name. Note: this is just a name, not a semantic type.
Returns:
the object or null if not found

getListeners

java.util.Collection<IThinklabSessionListener> getListeners()
Return all the listeners registered with the session. Can return null if no listeners are registered or allowed.

Returns:
a collection of all listeners added to the session using addListener(), or null.
